title: SaaS Market Entry - Southeast Asia
candidate_prompt: Our client is CloudMetrics, a US-based B2B SaaS company that provides analytics dashboards for enterprise customers. They have $50M in annual revenue and are considering expanding into Southeast Asia. The CEO wants to know: should they enter this market, and if so, how?
case_objectives: Evaluate market attractiveness of Southeast Asia
Assess company's right to win in this market

level_1.name: Fail
indicators: No clear framework for evaluating market entry
Jumps to conclusion without analysis (e.g., 'Yes, they should expand')
No consideration of market attractiveness or company fit
Cannot identify relevant factors for the decision
Generic statements without context (e.g., 'Asia is growing')
No understanding of B2B SaaS dynamics
level_1.example: Southeast Asia is a big market and growing fast, so they should definitely enter. They could open an office there.

level_2.name: Weak / Low Pass
indicators: Basic market vs company framing
Lists generic factors (market size, competition) without prioritization
No hypothesis about whether entry makes sense
Asks for data without knowing what to test
Considers only one entry mode
Recommendations lack specificity
level_2.example: I'd look at market size, competition, and whether they have the resources. Can I see data on the market? They could either go alone or partner.

level_3.name: Good But Not Enough
indicators: Clear framework: market attractiveness + right to win
Identifies relevant factors specific to B2B SaaS
Asks reasonable questions about TAM, competition, challenges
Compares entry modes with basic trade-offs
Provides recommendation but lacks conviction or detail
Limited consideration of risks or implementation
level_3.example: I'd structure this as: Is the market attractive? Can they win? How should they enter? The market seems attractive at $2B growing 25%. I'd want to understand competition and their capabilities.

level_4.name: Clear Pass
indicators: Comprehensive framework with clear decision criteria
Identifies key challenges specific to SEA (localization, payments, data residency)
Evaluates multiple entry modes with clear trade-offs
Shows understanding of B2B SaaS economics (CAC, LTV, payback)
Prioritized recommendation with supporting logic
Considers phasing, risks, and success metrics
level_4.example: Market entry decisions require: market attractiveness, right to win, and entry mode analysis. Given $2B TAM at 25% growth with low competition, the market is attractive. Key question is their ability to localize and sell relationship-driven deals.

level_5.name: Outstanding
indicators: Clear, logical decision framework tailored to context
Strong hypothesis about market fit and entry approach
Identifies nuanced challenges (country variation, local payments, data sovereignty)
Compares entry modes with quantitative reasoning
Recommends specific beachhead market with rationale
Actionable recommendation with milestones and risk mitigation
Demonstrates commercial awareness of SaaS metrics
level_5.example: This is a classic 'where to play, how to win' question. My hypothesis is the market is attractive but execution risk is high. I'd evaluate: market (TAM/SAM by country), capability gaps (localization, sales model), and entry economics. Singapore as beachhead makes sense given enterprise concentration.

challenges.payment_methods: Credit card penetration low, need local payment options
challenges.data_residency: Some countries require local data storage

options.organic_expansion: Open Singapore office, hire local team ($2M first year)
options.partnership: Partner with local system integrator (15% revenue share)
options.acquisition: Acquire local competitor DataViz Asia ($10M, 50 customers)

exploration_areas.description: How candidate frames and structures the market entry decision
exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: Clear framework with market attractiveness, right to win, entry mode analysis; forms hypothesis about key decision factors
exploration_areas.what_bad_looks_like: No framework, jumps to yes/no without structure, lists random considerations

exploration_areas.description: Whether candidate forms hypotheses before diving into data
exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: Clear hypothesis about market fit, asks targeted questions to test assumptions
exploration_areas.what_bad_looks_like: Asks for all data without knowing what to test, no clear thesis

exploration_areas.description: How candidate evaluates the Southeast Asian market opportunity
exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: Considers TAM/SAM/SOM, growth drivers, adoption curve, competitive dynamics; segments by country
exploration_areas.what_bad_looks_like: Generic questions not specific to B2B SaaS or region, no understanding of market attractiveness

exploration_areas.description: Identifying challenges specific to Southeast Asia market entry
exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: Comprehensive coverage of localization, payments, data sovereignty, relationship selling; prioritizes challenges with mitigation ideas
exploration_areas.what_bad_looks_like: Cannot identify meaningful challenges, generic 'it's risky' without specifics

exploration_areas.description: Evaluating different ways to enter the market
exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: Evaluates build/buy/partner options with clear criteria, considers phasing and beachhead strategy, quantitative comparison
exploration_areas.what_bad_looks_like: Only considers one option without alternatives or trade-offs, no understanding of entry modes

exploration_areas.description: Quality and prioritization of final recommendation
exploration_areas.what_good_looks_like: CEO-ready recommendation with market entry sequence, investment ask, milestones, risk mitigation
exploration_areas.what_bad_looks_like: No clear recommendation, contradicts analysis, wishy-washy answer
